steps.message:
You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action

Task Description:
I will ask you a question, then you should help me operate a MySQL database with SQL to answer the question.
You have to explain the problem and your solution to me and write down your thoughts.
After thinking and explaining thoroughly, every round you can choose to operate or to answer.
your operation should be like this:
Action: Operation
```sql
SELECT * FROM table WHERE condition;
```
You MUST put SQL in markdown format without any other comments. Your SQL should be in one line.
Every time you can only execute one SQL statement. I will only execute the statement in the first SQL code block. Every time you write a SQL, I will execute it for you and give you the output.
If you are done operating, and you want to commit your final answer, then write down:
Action: Answer
Final Answer: ["ANSWER1", "ANSWER2", ...]
DO NOT write this pattern unless you are sure about your answer. I expect an accurate and correct answer.
Your answer should be accurate. Your answer must be exactly the same as the correct answer.
If the question is about modifying the database, then after done operation, your answer field can be anything.
If your response cannot match any pattern I mentioned earlier, you will be judged as FAIL immediately.
Your input will be raw MySQL response, you have to deal with it by yourself.

Current terminal state:
Current Terminal Screen:
bash: cannot set terminal process group (-1): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
root@3bb7aeb36b74:/app#

steps.message:
{
  "analysis": "The mysql client is installed and available at /usr/bin/mysql. There is no MySQL server running in this container and no external DB connection details have been provided yet. I cannot execute any SQL until you either (A) give me connection details for an existing MySQL server (host, port or socket, user, password, database) and the SQL question you want answered, or (B) confirm you want me to install and start a local MySQL/MariaDB server here (and optionally provide data to load).",
  "plan": "Tell me which option you want:

- If you want to query an external database (Option A): provide connection details (host, port or socket path), credentials (user and password), and the database name, plus the question you want answered. I will then produce exactly one SQL statement per round in the required format so you can execute it and return the raw MySQL output.

- If you want a local server here (Option B): confirm and say whether to install mysql-server or mariadb-server, and whether to initialize sample data. I will install, start the server, create a database/user as needed, and then proceed to run queries per your questions, following the one-SQL-statement-per-round rule.

Once you choose and provide the necessary details or question, I will output the next single SQL statement in the required format.",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

{
  "analysis": "We have an Ubuntu 24.04 container with the MySQL client installed at /usr/bin/mysql. There is no MySQL server running here and no external database connection details or a SQL question have been provided. So far I have: updated apt, installed default-mysql-client, and verified the client is present. What remains: either connect to an existing database (need connection details and the SQL question) or install and start a local database server and/or load data so we can run queries locally.",
  "plan": "I will not run further commands until you choose how to proceed. Please pick one of the two options below and provide the requested details:

Option A — Query an existing (external) MySQL server:
- Provide connection details: host (or socket path), port (if nonstandard), user, password, and database name.
- Provide the exact question you want answered (describe desired output or columns/filters).
Once you provide those, I will produce exactly one SQL statement in the required format (Action: Operation with a single-line SQL code block). You will execute that SQL and return the raw MySQL output; we will iterate until the question is answered.

Option B — Create a local MySQL/MariaDB server in this container:
- Tell me whether to install mysql-server or mariadb-server.
- Tell me whether you want sample data loaded and, if so, provide the data or instructions for loading it.
If you confirm, I will: apt-get install the server package, initialize/start the service, create a database/user as needed, and then run queries per your requests. Each query will be provided one SQL statement per round in the required format.

Notes about the workflow and constraints:
- Every time I provide SQL to run, I will present exactly one SQL statement inside a single markdown code block prefixed by: Action: Operation. You must execute only the SQL in the first code block and return the MySQL output. We will repeat until you are satisfied.
- When you are done and want the final answer (not further DB operations), instruct me and I will produce: Action: Answer Final Answer: ["ANS1","ANS2", ...]

Tell me which option you choose and give the required details (or the SQL question if you already have connection info).",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

{
  "analysis": "The container is Ubuntu 24.04 and the MySQL client (/usr/bin/mysql) is installed. There is no MySQL server running here and you have not provided any external database connection details or a SQL question yet. No SQL has been executed against a database because there is nothing to connect to.",
  "plan": "I will wait for you to choose how to proceed. You have two main choices:

Option A — Query an existing (external) MySQL server:
- Provide connection details: host (or socket path), port (if nonstandard), user, password, and database name.
- Provide the exact question you want answered (what data or aggregation you need).
After you provide these, I will produce exactly one SQL statement in the required format (Action: Operation with a single-line SQL code block). You will run that SQL and return the raw mysql output; we will iterate until the question is answered.

Option B — Create and use a local database in this container:
- Tell me whether to install mysql-server or mariadb-server here (I can install and start it).
- Tell me if you want sample data loaded and provide that data or instructions.
If you confirm, I will install/start the server, create the database/user if needed, and then proceed to run queries per your requests. Each round I'll produce exactly one SQL statement for you to run.

Important workflow notes:
- Every time I provide SQL it will be exactly one statement inside a single markdown code block prefixed by: Action: Operation. You must execute only the SQL in the first code block and return the raw MySQL output.
- When you are ready for a final answer (no more DB operations), tell me and I will produce: Action: Answer Final Answer: ["ANS1","ANS2", ...]

Tell me which option you choose and provide the necessary connection details or the SQL question, and I will produce the next single SQL statement.",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

{
  "analysis": "You are in a container (Ubuntu 24.04) with the MySQL client installed (/usr/bin/mysql). There is no MySQL server running locally and you have not supplied any external database connection details or a SQL question yet. I have prepared the environment (installed default-mysql-client) but no SQL has been executed against any database because we don't have a target DB or query to run.",
  "plan": "I will wait for you to choose how to proceed and provide the required details. Two clear options:

Option A — Query an existing (external) MySQL server (recommended if you already have a DB):
- Provide the connection details: host (or socket path), port (if nonstandard), user, password, and database name.

Option B — Create and use a local database in this container:
- Tell me whether to install mysql-server or mariadb-server here.
- Tell me whether you want sample data loaded (if so, provide the data or a description of the schema and sample rows) or whether to initialize an empty DB and I'll create example data.
If you confirm, I'll install and start the server, create a database/user as needed, and then proceed to run queries. Each round I will provide exactly one SQL statement for you to run.

Connection examples and what I'll need when you choose Option A (examples only — do not run these until you confirm):
- TCP connection example: mysql -h <host> -P <port> -u <user> -p<password> <database>
- Socket connection example: mysql --socket=/path/to/mysql.sock -u <user> -p<password> <database>

When you provide the connection details and the specific question, I'll produce the first SQL statement in the required format. If you want me to set up a local server, confirm which server (mysql-server or mariadb-server) and whether to load data.

Next action: Please choose Option A or Option B and provide the required details (connection info + question, or server choice + data instructions).",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}
